A robust proof of the instability of naked singularities of a scalar field in spherical symmetry

Jue Liu Department of Mathematics, Sun Yat-sen University
Guangzhou, China liuj337@mail2.sysu.edu.cn  and  Junbin Li Department of Mathematics, Sun Yat-sen University
Guangzhou, China lijunbin@mail.sysu.edu.cn
Abstract.

Published in 1999, Christodoulou proved that the naked singularities of a self-gravitating scalar field are not stable in spherical symmetry and therefore the cosmic censorship conjecture is true in this context. The original proof is by contradiction and sharp estimates are obtained strictly depending on spherical symmetry. In this paper, appropriate a priori estimates for the solution are obtained. These estimates are more relaxed but sufficient for giving another robust argument in proving the instability, in particular not by contradiction. In another related paper, we are able to prove instability theorems of the spherical symmetric naked singularities under certain isotropic gravitational perturbations without symmetries. The argument given in this paper plays a central role.

Both authors are supported by NSFC 11501582, 11521101.

1. Introduction

In the paper [4], Christodoulou proved both the weak cosmic censorship conjecture and the strong cosmic censorship conjecture for spherically symmetric solutions of the Einstein equations coupled with a massless scalar field. The coupled system reads

𝐑𝐢𝐜α​β−12​𝐑​gα​β=𝐓α​β=∇αϕ​∇βϕ−12​gα​β​gμ​ν​∇μϕ​∇νϕ,subscript𝐑𝐢𝐜𝛼𝛽12𝐑subscript𝑔𝛼𝛽subscript𝐓𝛼𝛽subscript∇𝛼italic-ϕsubscript∇𝛽italic-ϕ12subscript𝑔𝛼𝛽superscript𝑔𝜇𝜈subscript∇𝜇italic-ϕsubscript∇𝜈italic-ϕ\displaystyle\mathbf{Ric}_{\alpha\beta}-\frac{1}{2}\mathbf{R}g_{\alpha\beta}=\mathbf{T}_{\alpha\beta}=\nabla_{\alpha}\phi\nabla_{\beta}\phi-\frac{1}{2}g_{\alpha\beta}g^{\mu\nu}\nabla_{\mu}\phi\nabla_{\nu}\phi,

which we call the Einstein-scalar field equations. The proof, which is by contradiction, contains sharp estimates which may not be easily obtained beyond spherical symmetry. In this paper, we will provide a robust proof which is not by contradiction and contains only relaxed estimates. The main advantage of this proof is that it has the potential to be extended beyond spherical symmetry.

Consider the characteristic initial value problem of the Einstein-scalar field equations in spherical symmetry. The initial data is given on a null cone Cosubscript𝐶𝑜C_{o} issuing from a fixed point o𝑜o of the symmetry group S​O​(3)𝑆𝑂3SO(3), and consists of a function α0=∂∂r​(r​ϕ)|Cosubscript𝛼0evaluated-at𝑟𝑟italic-ϕsubscript𝐶𝑜\alpha_{0}=\frac{\partial}{\partial r}(r\phi)\big{|}_{C_{o}} defining on [0,+∞)0[0,+\infty), where r𝑟r is area radius of the orbit spherical sections of Cosubscript𝐶𝑜C_{o}, and ϕitalic-ϕ\phi is the scalar field function. Then what was exactly proved by Christodoulou is the following theorem.

Theorem 1 (Christodoulou).

Let ℰℰ\mathcal{E} be the complement of the collection of functions α0∈B​Vsubscript𝛼0𝐵𝑉\alpha_{0}\in BV whose maximal future development is either complete, or possesses a complete future null infinity and a strictly spacelike singular future boundary. Then if α0∈ℰsubscript𝛼0ℰ\alpha_{0}\in\mathcal{E}, then there exists some f∈B​V𝑓𝐵𝑉f\in BV such that α0+λ​f∉ℰsubscript𝛼0𝜆𝑓ℰ\alpha_{0}+\lambda f\notin\mathcal{E} and has non-complete maximal future development for all λ≠0𝜆0\lambda\neq 0. Moreover, if α0+λ​f≡α0′+λ′​f′subscript𝛼0𝜆𝑓superscriptsubscript𝛼0′superscript𝜆′superscript𝑓′\alpha_{0}+\lambda f\equiv\alpha_{0}^{\prime}+\lambda^{\prime}f^{\prime}, then α0≡α0′subscript𝛼0superscriptsubscript𝛼0′\alpha_{0}\equiv\alpha_{0}^{\prime}, f≡f′𝑓superscript𝑓′f\equiv f^{\prime} and λ=λ′𝜆superscript𝜆′\lambda=\lambda^{\prime}.

We may therefore say that the exceptional set ℰℰ\mathcal{E} is of codimension at least 111. The proof can roughly be divided into three steps. Consider an arbitrary initial data α0∈B​Vsubscript𝛼0𝐵𝑉\alpha_{0}\in BV. The first step is, which was shown in [3], that the maximal future development of such data is complete, unless there exists a singular endpoint e𝑒e of the central timelike geodesic ΓΓ\Gamma from o𝑜o. A sharp criterion of the appearance of e𝑒e was also found: 2​mr↛0↛2𝑚𝑟0\frac{2m}{r}\nrightarrow 0 when approaching e𝑒e, where m𝑚m is the mass function. The second step is to understand how an apparent horizon forms. We have the following theorem also by Christodoulou.

Theorem 2 (Christodoulou, [2]).

Consider the spherically symmetric solution of the Einstein-scalar field equations with initial data given on a null cone Cosubscript𝐶𝑜C_{o}. Let S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} and S2subscript𝑆2S_{2} be two sphercal sections with area radii r1subscript𝑟1r_{1}, r2subscript𝑟2r_{2} and mass contents m1subscript𝑚1m_{1}, m2subscript𝑚2m_{2}, and S2subscript𝑆2S_{2} is in the exterior to S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}. Denote

δ=r2r1−1.𝛿subscript𝑟2subscript𝑟11\delta=\frac{r_{2}}{r_{1}}-1.

Then there exists positive constants c0subscript𝑐0c_{0}, c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} such that if δ≤c0𝛿subscript𝑐0\delta\leq c_{0} and

2​(m2−m1)>c1​r2​δ​log⁡(1δ),2subscript𝑚2subscript𝑚1subscript𝑐1subscript𝑟2𝛿1𝛿\displaystyle 2(m_{2}-m_{1})>c_{1}r_{2}\delta\log\left(\frac{1}{\delta}\right),

then the incoming null cone through S2subscript𝑆2S_{2} intersects the apparent horizon and enters the trapped region, the region of trapped surfaces. Moreover, there exists an event horizon and the trapped region terminates at a spacelike singular boundary.

Inspired by this theorem, we then consider the future of C¯e​⋃Cosubscript¯𝐶𝑒subscript𝐶𝑜\underline{C}_{e}\bigcup C_{o}, where C¯esubscript¯𝐶𝑒\underline{C}_{e} is the boundary of the causal past of e𝑒e and intersects Cosubscript𝐶𝑜C_{o} at s=se𝑠subscript𝑠𝑒s=s_{e}. Then the last step, what was really proved in [4] is that, allowing a perturbation on α0subscript𝛼0\alpha_{0}, there exists a sequence pn∈Γsubscript𝑝𝑛Γp_{n}\in\Gamma where pn→e→subscript𝑝𝑛𝑒p_{n}\to e such that the null cone Cpnsubscript𝐶subscript𝑝𝑛C_{p_{n}} issuing from pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} satisfies the assumptions of Theorem 2 at two spheres S1,nsubscript𝑆1𝑛S_{1,n} and S2,nsubscript𝑆2𝑛S_{2,n} on Cpnsubscript𝐶subscript𝑝𝑛C_{p_{n}}, between which the distance tends to zero. The corresponding spacetimes have an event horizon and therefore possess a complete future null infinity, which verifies the weak cosmic censorship conjecture. Moreover, the distance of S1,nsubscript𝑆1𝑛S_{1,n} and S2,nsubscript𝑆2𝑛S_{2,n} tending to zero implies that the apparent horizon issues from e𝑒e and therefore the future boundary of the maximal development is spacelike and singular. This verifies the strong cosmic censorship conjecture.

In this paper, we are going to give a new argument of this last step. We would like to give a statement of this single step. First of all, we introduce a double null coordinate (u¯,u)¯𝑢𝑢(\underline{u},u) of the quotient spacetime relative to the singular endpoint e𝑒e of ΓΓ\Gamma as follows. Let u¯¯𝑢\underline{u} and u𝑢u be optical functions, i.e., their level sets, which we denote by C¯u¯subscript¯𝐶¯𝑢\underline{C}_{\underline{u}} and Cusubscript𝐶𝑢C_{u}, are incoming and outgoing null cones respectively. We take u¯=0,u=−rformulae-sequence¯𝑢0𝑢𝑟\underline{u}=0,u=-r on C¯esubscript¯𝐶𝑒\underline{C}_{e}, and take u=u0𝑢subscript𝑢0u=u_{0} and u¯¯𝑢\underline{u} increasing towards the future on Cosubscript𝐶𝑜C_{o} where −u0=r0subscript𝑢0subscript𝑟0-u_{0}=r_{0} is the area radius of the sphere C¯e​⋂Cosubscript¯𝐶𝑒subscript𝐶𝑜\underline{C}_{e}\bigcap C_{o}. Using this notation, we will write C¯e=C¯0subscript¯𝐶𝑒subscript¯𝐶0\underline{C}_{e}=\underline{C}_{0}, Co=Cu0subscript𝐶𝑜subscript𝐶subscript𝑢0C_{o}=C_{u_{0}}. In terms of the double null coordinate (u¯,u)¯𝑢𝑢(\underline{u},u) relative to e𝑒e, what we are going to reprove can be stated as follows.

Theorem 3.

Let ℰℰ\mathcal{E} be the complement of the collection of functions α0∈B​Vsubscript𝛼0𝐵𝑉\alpha_{0}\in BV whose maximal future development is either complete or has the property, that if e𝑒e is the singular endpoint of ΓΓ\Gamma and (u¯,u)¯𝑢𝑢(\underline{u},u) is the double null coordinate relative to e𝑒e, then there exists two sequences δn→0+→subscript𝛿𝑛superscript0\delta_{n}\to 0^{+} and un→0−→subscript𝑢𝑛superscript0u_{n}\to 0^{-} such that

where m𝑚m and r𝑟r take values at (u¯,u)=(δn,un)¯𝑢𝑢subscript𝛿𝑛subscript𝑢𝑛(\underline{u},u)=(\delta_{n},u_{n}), mn=m​(0,un)subscript𝑚𝑛𝑚0subscript𝑢𝑛m_{n}=m(0,u_{n}), rn=|un|subscript𝑟𝑛subscript𝑢𝑛r_{n}=|u_{n}| and c0,c1subscript𝑐0subscript𝑐1c_{0},c_{1} are the constants given in Theorem 2. Then if α0∈ℰsubscript𝛼0ℰ\alpha_{0}\in\mathcal{E}, then there exists two functions f1,f2∈B​Vsubscript𝑓1subscript𝑓2𝐵𝑉f_{1},f_{2}\in BV, such that α0+λ1​f1+λ2​f2∉ℰsubscript𝛼0subscript𝜆1subscript𝑓1subscript𝜆2subscript𝑓2ℰ\alpha_{0}+\lambda_{1}f_{1}+\lambda_{2}f_{2}\notin\mathcal{E} and has non-complete maximal future development for all λ1,λ2subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2} with λ1≠0subscript𝜆10\lambda_{1}\neq 0 or λ2≠0subscript𝜆20\lambda_{2}\neq 0. Moreover, if α0+λ1​f1+λ2​f2≡α0′+λ1′​f1′+λ2′​f2′subscript𝛼0subscript𝜆1subscript𝑓1subscript𝜆2subscript𝑓2superscriptsubscript𝛼0′superscriptsubscript𝜆1′subscriptsuperscript𝑓′1superscriptsubscript𝜆2′subscriptsuperscript𝑓′2\alpha_{0}+\lambda_{1}f_{1}+\lambda_{2}f_{2}\equiv\alpha_{0}^{\prime}+\lambda_{1}^{\prime}f^{\prime}_{1}+\lambda_{2}^{\prime}f^{\prime}_{2}, then α0≡α0′subscript𝛼0superscriptsubscript𝛼0′\alpha_{0}\equiv\alpha_{0}^{\prime}, f1≡f1′subscript𝑓1subscriptsuperscript𝑓′1f_{1}\equiv f^{\prime}_{1}, f2≡f2′subscript𝑓2subscriptsuperscript𝑓′2f_{2}\equiv f^{\prime}_{2} and λ1=λ1′subscript𝜆1superscriptsubscript𝜆1′\lambda_{1}=\lambda_{1}^{\prime}, λ2=λ2′subscript𝜆2superscriptsubscript𝜆2′\lambda_{2}=\lambda_{2}^{\prime}.

Remark 1.

As in [4], we will also reprove this theorem where the exceptional set ℰℰ\mathcal{E} is of codimension at least 222, which is stronger than what we state in Theorem 1. Both in Christodoulou’s proof and the proof in this paper, f2subscript𝑓2f_{2} is shown to be absolutely continuous, and therefore the conclusions of Theorem 1 hold for α0subscript𝛼0\alpha_{0} being absolutely continuous, which is of course more regular than being of bounded variation.

In proving this theorem, instead of using double null coordinate, Christodoulou worked in a dimensionless coordinate (s,t)𝑠𝑡(s,t) relative to the singular endpoint e𝑒e:

u=u0​e−t,−2​r=u0​es−t,formulae-sequence𝑢subscript𝑢0superscripte𝑡2𝑟subscript𝑢0superscripte𝑠𝑡\displaystyle u=u_{0}\mathrm{e}^{-t},\ -2r=u_{0}\mathrm{e}^{s-t},

and the first step of the proof by contradiction is to assume that given any ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, the opposite of (1.1), i.e.,

2​(m​(s,t)−m​(0,t))≤c1​r​(s,t)​s​log⁡(1s)2𝑚𝑠𝑡𝑚0𝑡subscript𝑐1𝑟𝑠𝑡𝑠1𝑠\displaystyle 2(m(s,t)-m(0,t))\leq c_{1}r(s,t)s\log\left(\frac{1}{s}\right) (1.2)

holds in {0≤s≤c0}​⋂{0≤u¯≤ε}0𝑠subscript𝑐00¯𝑢𝜀\{0\leq s\leq c_{0}\}\bigcap\{0\leq\underline{u}\leq\varepsilon\}. For the Einstein-scalar field system, the mass m𝑚m governs the whole system and has good monotone properties. Christodoulou was able to estimate all related geometric quantities in a sharp way in terms of m​(s,t)−m​(0,t)𝑚𝑠𝑡𝑚0𝑡m(s,t)-m(0,t), which is bounded from (1.2), and use these estimates to find some (sε,tε)∈{0≤s≤c0}​⋂{0≤u¯≤ε}subscript𝑠𝜀subscript𝑡𝜀0𝑠subscript𝑐00¯𝑢𝜀(s_{\varepsilon},t_{\varepsilon})\in\{0\leq s\leq c_{0}\}\bigcap\{0\leq\underline{u}\leq\varepsilon\} such that the opposite of (1.2) holds for some particular (s,t)=(sε,tε)𝑠𝑡subscript𝑠𝜀subscript𝑡𝜀(s,t)=(s_{\varepsilon},t_{\varepsilon}), which is a contradiction.

However, in order to extend this result beyond spherical symmetry, much more things need to be concerned. First of all, we need to derive suitable a priori estimates in order to establish the existence of the solution. Second, we may not benefit from the assumptions like (1.2) which is from proof by contradiction because the mass, which is essentially the L2superscript𝐿2L^{2} integral of L​ϕ𝐿italic-ϕL\phi (together with the outgoing shear) over Cusubscript𝐶𝑢C_{u}, can no longer govern the whole system without symmetries. In addition, the estimates derived by Christodoulou is so sharp that it is not easy to extend them beyond spherical symmetry.

In this paper, we are able to derive a priori L∞superscript𝐿L^{\infty} bounds of the geometric quantities, including ∂∂u¯​ϕ¯𝑢italic-ϕ\frac{\partial}{\partial\underline{u}}\phi, ∂∂u​ϕ𝑢italic-ϕ\frac{\partial}{\partial u}\phi, and the derivatives of r𝑟r and ΩΩ\Omega defined by −2​Ω2=g​(∂∂u¯,∂∂u)2superscriptΩ2𝑔¯𝑢𝑢-2\Omega^{2}=g\left(\frac{\partial}{\partial\underline{u}},\frac{\partial}{\partial u}\right). These a priori estimates are proved by bootstrap argument to hold in a region deep enough to the future. It then follows easily that the condition (1.1) eventually holds before these estimates fail. These estimates are robust and analogues of them may hold when no symmetries are imposed. The generalization of these estimates without symmetries will also be used in proving the existence. There is a simple way to understand the difference between two arguments, that is, the a priori estimates we derive will in particular imply that some analogue of the assumption (1.2) really holds with c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} replaced by a larger constant depending on the L∞superscript𝐿L^{\infty} bounds of the data on Cosubscript𝐶𝑜C_{o} and this condition with a larger constant still implies that (1.1) holds by Christodoulou’s argument. Nevertheless, we do not need to repeat Christodoulou’s argument because from the bootstrap argument, all estimates are obtained simultaneously and (1.1) is then simply a direct conclusion.

The new argument presented in this paper can possibly be extended to the case when no symmetries are assumed. In an another paper [6] by the authors, we consider the characteristic initial value problem of the Einstein-scalar field equations, with the initial data given on two null cones intersecting at a sphere. The incoming null cone is assumed to be spherically symmetric and singular at its vertex, in the sense that 2​mr↛0↛2𝑚𝑟0\frac{2m}{r}\nrightarrow 0 when approaching it. No symmetries are imposed on the outgoing null cone. Then we will show that the argument presented in this paper can be directly generalized and we can also prove an instability theorem like Theorem 1. We suggest the readers refer to [6] for the precise statement. Finally, we should also mention that the estimates derived in this paper, and also in [6], share many common features with those in the work of An-Luk [1] where they worked with the spacetime region deep near the vertex which is regular. Readers may also refer to [6] for some discussions about this.

2. Double null coordinates and equations

2.1. Double null coordinate

The spherically symmetric spacetime can be studied through its 2-dimensional quotient spacetime manifold with boundary ΓΓ\Gamma, the fixed point set of the S​O​(3)𝑆𝑂3SO(3) action, being a timelike geodesic, which we call the central line. We use a double null coordinate (u¯,u)¯𝑢𝑢(\underline{u},u), where u¯¯𝑢\underline{u}, u𝑢u are optical functions, which means that their level sets C¯u¯subscript¯𝐶¯𝑢\underline{C}_{\underline{u}} and Cusubscript𝐶𝑢C_{u} are incoming and outgoing null cones invariant under the S​O​(3)𝑆𝑂3SO(3) action respectively. In the quotient spacetime, C¯u¯subscript¯𝐶¯𝑢\underline{C}_{\underline{u}} and Cusubscript𝐶𝑢C_{u} are then incoming and outgoing null lines respectively. We then denote

L=∂∂u¯,L¯=∂∂u,formulae-sequence𝐿¯𝑢¯𝐿𝑢\displaystyle L=\frac{\partial}{\partial\underline{u}},\ \underline{L}=\frac{\partial}{\partial u},

and define the lapse function ΩΩ\Omega by

−2​Ω2=g​(L,L¯).2superscriptΩ2𝑔𝐿¯𝐿\displaystyle-2\Omega^{2}=g(L,\underline{L}).

Then the metric has the form

where the area radius function r=r​(u¯,u)𝑟𝑟¯𝑢𝑢r=r(\underline{u},u) is defined by

Area​(Su¯,u)=4​π​r2,Areasubscript𝑆¯𝑢𝑢4𝜋superscript𝑟2\displaystyle\text{Area}(S_{\underline{u},u})=4\pi r^{2},

and d​σ𝕊2dsubscript𝜎superscript𝕊2\mathrm{d}\sigma_{\mathbb{S}^{2}} is the standard metric of the unit sphere.

3. A priori bounds for the solution

We begin the proof of Theorem 3. Recall that we start from an arbitrary initial data α0∈B​Vsubscript𝛼0𝐵𝑉\alpha_{0}\in BV and the central line has a singular endpoint e𝑒e, approaching which 2​mr↛0↛2𝑚𝑟0\frac{2m}{r}\nrightarrow 0. Both Ω02​h0superscriptsubscriptΩ02subscriptℎ0\Omega_{0}^{2}h_{0} and Ω0subscriptΩ0\Omega_{0} are monotonically decreasing and converge to 00 as u→0−→𝑢superscript0u\to 0^{-}.

Remark 2.

The proof in the following then depends only on the fact that Ω0→0→subscriptΩ00\Omega_{0}\to 0 monotonically. The infiniteness of the integral in (3.2) depends strictly on the monotonicity of mass m𝑚m along C¯0subscript¯𝐶0\underline{C}_{0}. We do not expect a robust argument of this proof since the criteria 2​mr↛0↛2𝑚𝑟0\frac{2m}{r}\nrightarrow 0 may not make sense beyond spherical symmetry. A robust version of this lemma, which is beyond reach right now, should include another suitable criteria in general case which is still an active area of research.

4. Instability theorems

the conclusion follows using the argument in the proof of Theorem 5.

To this end, we go back to equation (3.19). Integrating it on Cunsubscript𝐶subscript𝑢𝑛C_{u_{n}} leads to

The right hand side can be estimated similarly to the estimate of the error terms in (3.20). Then we have, for n𝑛n sufficiently large,

|r​L​ϕ​(u¯,un)|≥|r​L​ϕ​(u¯,u0)+(φn−φ​(u0))|−c​δ​|un|−1​Φ2​𝒲n12𝑟𝐿italic-ϕ¯𝑢subscript𝑢𝑛𝑟𝐿italic-ϕ¯𝑢subscript𝑢0subscript𝜑𝑛𝜑subscript𝑢0𝑐𝛿superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑛1superscriptΦ2superscriptsubscript𝒲𝑛12\displaystyle|rL\phi(\underline{u},u_{n})|\geq|rL\phi(\underline{u},u_{0})+(\varphi_{n}-\varphi(u_{0}))|-c\delta|u_{n}|^{-1}\Phi^{2}\mathscr{W}_{n}^{\frac{1}{2}}

for some constant c𝑐c depending on the initial bound of L​ϕ𝐿italic-ϕL\phi on Cu0subscript𝐶subscript𝑢0C_{u_{0}}. Now from (4.3) again,

which is the desired inequality.  

Remark 3.

It is worth mentioning that in Christodoulou’s original proof, when φ​(u)𝜑𝑢\varphi(u) is bounded but not tends to zero, the conclusions of Theorem 5 holds without any additional conditions like (4.2). Indeed, the condition (4.2) is slightly different from that in Christodoulou’s proof and we can see when φ​(u)𝜑𝑢\varphi(u) is bounded but not tends to zero, (4.2) holds identically because r​L​ϕ​(u¯,u0)𝑟𝐿italic-ϕ¯𝑢subscript𝑢0rL\phi(\underline{u},u_{0}) is of bounded variation and hence can be made right-continuous.

The remaining part of the proof of Theorem 3 is then similar to that in the last section in [4]. We still present the proof here for the sake of completeness.
